page.title: 02Local History
page.content: In prehistoric times the tribes of the Otalini and the Gadeni had a northern frontier town called Alauna, the situation of which coresponds with that of Inchkeith. Several chisel-like tools from the prehistoric time have been found on the island. Nothing of interest seems to have occurred on Inchkeith until the reign of James IV (1488-1513). In 1497, the Edingurgh Privy Council, under orders from the King, instructed the Magistrates to assemble all those suffering from the plague and transport them to Inchkeith. Under his successor, James V (1513-1542), the island was gifted under the Great Seal to Sir Andrew Wood of Largo, upon the forfeiture of John, Lord Glamis. From this time until after World War II the main use of Inchkeith was as a military base.
